claim: A jumping spider would need over half a dozen contact lenses.

supporting.text: Jumping spiders have excellent vision with their multiple eyes, eliminating the need for contact lenses.

attacks.text: Jumping spiders have excellent vision with their multiple eyes, eliminating the need for contact lenses.
Jumping spiders' vision is optimized for detecting motion and hunting, not for tasks requiring precision like reading or detailed object recognition.
Even with excellent motion detection, jumping spiders may still benefit from corrective lenses if their vision is impaired due to injury or environmental factors.
There is no evidence that jumping spiders suffer from vision impairments that would require corrective lenses.

supporting.text: Contact lenses are designed for human eyes and are not applicable to the anatomy of jumping spiders.

attacks.text: Contact lenses are designed for human eyes and are not applicable to the anatomy of jumping spiders.
Specialized contact lenses can be custom-made for non-human species, including spiders.
The cost and practicality of creating spider-sized contact lenses make this highly unlikely for common use.
Research in micro-optics has demonstrated the feasibility of creating lenses for small arthropods.

supporting.text: Jumping spiders have evolved to hunt and navigate without any artificial visual aids.

attacks.text: Jumping spiders have evolved to hunt and navigate without any artificial visual aids.
Jumping spiders have multiple pairs of eyes with different focal lengths, which could theoretically require corrective lenses for optimal vision.
The natural resolution and adaptability of jumping spider eyes are sufficient for their ecological needs, making artificial aids unnecessary.
Some jumping spiders exhibit behaviors that suggest imperfect vision, such as misjudging distances when jumping.

supporting.text: There is no scientific or practical basis for fitting contact lenses to jumping spiders.

attacks.text: There is no scientific or practical basis for fitting contact lenses to jumping spiders.
Jumping spiders have complex eyes that could theoretically benefit from corrective lenses if they had vision impairments.
There is no evidence that jumping spiders suffer from vision impairments that would require corrective lenses.
Even if jumping spiders had vision impairments, their small size makes fitting contact lenses impractical.
